Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 02:07PM maxgirl wrote: I hear you, Stressin.  At least while we were getting treated, we could sort of relax into the routine and think we were actively fighting the BC.  I'm extremely happy to be done with treatment, but it does feel like the ground has been pulled from under my feet. I've "known" that the BC issue was going to hang over my head for a long, long time, if not forever, but it's upsetting to get hit over the head with it time and time again, and to be worried about any bump or pain. I keep trying to convince myself that worrying is not going to change a thing, but that sort of goes against my Irish-American  background, where, at least in my family, it's thought that if you worry hard enough about something, it won't happen.  Obviously I didn't worry hard enough about BC.
Posts.Title: Anyone anxious at end of rads treatment? Stressin67 arnica

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2007 01:16PM - edited Sep 22, 2007 01:18PM by maxgirl Hi, Mary Jo -- I finished DD 4 AC and 4 Taxol in June, and I pretty much agree with what everyone has said so far. You shouldn't feel worse before your next tx.  The fatigue does build up over the course of treatment, but I was able to work through mine, with days off for treatment and usually one other day (or working from home) for each tx. I have a desk job, though; I don't think I could have worked so much if it had been more physical. I had mouth problems that didn't kick in until the second treatment, and I think food tasted worse and worse as I went along, but generally my reactions were pretty even. Some people do have a fairly easy time of it, and I hope you're one of them.  But definitely drink, drink, drink, and keep up with the anti-nausea meds. Good luck! Max

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2008 11:31AM maxgirl wrote:  Zuffa,  I'd just make sure you can spare enough of yourself and your energy for the other things in your life. I was 57 at diagnosis and 58+ by the time treatment ended.  I had DD AC+T and rads and worked right through.  I was lucky in that I could do some work from home, so the day after my Thursday treatment I'd put in a half day at home, then a few more hours over the weekend.  It got harder as I got more tired from the treatment, plus I developed pretty severe anemia (now resolved).  I used to say I was 80% "there" about 80% of the time.  Work did save my sanity, but if I had to do it over, I'd take some time off.  All I had energy for was work and treatment.  I missed helping my future DIL prepare for her and my son's wedding, and I missed spending more time with my mother, who died unexpectedly less than 5 months after I finished treatment.  It's worth considering what else besides work you want to expend your precious energy on. Best of luck to you on whatever path you take.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2009 07:51PM maxgirl wrote: I was seeing a neurologist for another reason and asked her about my balance problems and whether it could have anything to do with the mild neuropathy I have in my feet.   She said it was almost certainly caused by the neuropathy.  Part of our balance comes from the messages we get from our feet about where we are in relation to the ground.  The nerves damaged by neuropathy aren't sending this message as well.  I told her I feel I have tp "get my feet under me" when I stand up suddenly or turn around, and she said that's what it would be like.  Otter, I've flunked the closed-eye balance test, too, and it's because I'm not getting the right information from my feet.

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2007 08:03PM maxgirl wrote: Roxy -- When I got that tired, it turned out I was anemic.  I got 4 weekly shots of Procrit, and by the second shot, I was feeling better. It's normal to get tired right after chemo, but I think not being able to move for 3 days and having trouble walking is probably more than you should have to deal with.  Sometimes you have to make a little noise to get the docs to pay attention.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Tired roxy42 maxgirl

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2007 04:40AM - edited Sep 24, 2007 04:47AM by maxgirl I had an emotionally bad time with radiation, too, and each day I just dreaded treatment.  But I did a lot of research, and radiation cuts the risk of local recurrence dramatically.  Which is not to say that in 10 years we wouldn't be suffering some radiation-related illness. What I did balk on was rads to the supraclavicular area (above the breast, collarbone, that area).  The rad onc said because I was high grade and triple negative, that was the "standard" treatment.  But I couldn't find any studies to support it, and she couldn't cite any.  So I went through 19 treatments, waking up and going to sleep fretting about possible damage to the thyroid and throat -- and finally told the rad onc, no more to that area.   I finished the 25 regular rads and 8 boosts.   Once the regular treatment ended, even before boosts were over, the rest of my skin had started to heal.  The boost area got worse before it got better, but it's been fine for about a week now.  I ended rads 8/27. ETA: Tender, I wish any of my docs had explained things as clearly as you do.  I've seen other posts from you and always learn something new.  I  had a BS who called me an "information hound".  I fired him and found one more willing to talk and explain.  The rad onc I never got through to.  Guess I ended up short in the supraclav area.
Posts.Title: Has any one reduced number of radiation treatments? kam54 joanne_elizabeth

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2008 06:30PM maxgirl wrote: I'm no expert on LE, but I have been suffering from it in the same area you have, as well as some in my arm, and just offer my $0.02. I saw my primary recently and was complaining about the recurring LE in my breast and around to my side, and he said I could consider reduction surgery.  I don't see myself considering any elective surgery any time soon, but I'm going to talk to my PS about it when I see her next week. My LE therapist did some massage across my chest to encourage the flow that way, but what seemed to work best was massaging across my back.  It's different from regular massage because the lymph system is closer to the skin than the muscles are. You start at the opposite side of the back and do gentle pushes (think of trying to move your skin on the top of your muscles), working your way across to the affected side, but still pushing the other way.  As I understand it, what you're doing is clearing the other side so you can push the fluid from the affected area.   My husband has gotten very good at it!  Also, I can get a chair massage once a week at work, and the MT will do it for me as well.
Posts.Title: Seroma->->BreastLE?!?What about StageII Recon? LisaSDCA sccruiser

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2007 04:16PM maxgirl wrote: I've seen that article before, and it does give me pause, but the women they studied were treated between 1977 and 1995. Mapping and the accuracy of the radiation have gotten better over time, so I think they mean they would expect fewer cardiac problems in women treated more recently. I wish they'd shown when the women with the heart disease were treated.
Posts.Title: Left sided breast radiation effect on the heart... Marie_S_ Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2008 02:45AM - edited Aug 23, 2008 02:49AM by maxgirl I've had really good results with Kinesio tape, much to my surprise.  My LT tried it on me, and since it worked, I ordered several rolls for myself.  She showed me several different ways to use it and how to try different patterns. I use one strip along my lumpectomy scar, and it helps keep it softer, and also a wider band on the lower side of that breast, kind of tucking up under the nipple.  That one gives me support and also lessens the hardening of the nipple area. I tried it across my chest above the breasts, but it didn't seem to make much difference and interfered with my MLD, so I stopped that one.  This week I've experimented with 2 strips down the inside of my affected forearm, and they seem to be helping with a sore spot there. I keep the tape on for about 4 days, then take a day off to give my skin a rest.  My LT says it doesn't work the same way for everyone, but it's certainly worth a try. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Kinesio Tape -good results anyone? rrs maxgirl

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2008 05:50PM maxgirl wrote: I'm late to this topic, but I have Kaiser in the Mid-Atlantic region, and I was able to get a referral to an LT, but mostly because my surgeon is on top of these things (not my oncs -- they are true Kaiser "employees").  First I went out of plan to National Rehab Hospital LTs -- they did arm and neck MLD and wrapped my arm and did the pump, but could not handle my truncal LE.   My surgeon recommended a Kaiser LT who was 40 miles away, and she was worth every ounce of gas I paid for to get to her.  No pump, careful explanations, trunk and boob MLD in addition to the arm, work on fibrotic tissue, recommendations for exercise.  If I can shanghai the thread for a moment, SoCal Lisa, how did you change insurance?  I know HIPAA is supposed to make it possible, but then I always hear about women denied coverage because of a pre-existing condition,

Posts.Content: maxgirl wrote: I know -- in the great scheme of things and with everything else that can go wrong, this is not that important, but two years after I had rads, I'm still PO'd about those bloody blue dots.  I've got lymphedema, a little neuropathy, my hair and big toenails never came back right, and I have a metastasis scare at least once every 6 months, but it's the bloody blue dots that depress the heck out of me.    It feels like the only reason they were put there was for someone else's convenience.  Not all rad places use them, so some people can hit the target without permanently scarring their patients.  I don't suppose Kaiser will pay for laser treatments to remove them.   [/rant] Dx 1/10/2007, IDC, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 2/15 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2007 10:48PM maxgirl wrote: Hannah -- I actually did a quick one-day trip with one-hour flights during radiation.  I didn't need to fly again until 2 months after I finished. My concern was lymphedema, because I'd had some swelling in my arm after the node surgery.  So I saw a lymphedema therapist for treatment and also got a compression sleeve to wear on the flight. I didn't have any problems.  If I'd traveled 2 weeks after radiation, my only concern would have been fatigue, because I was pretty low-energy for about 6 weeks after treatment.  Two weeks should also be enough time for your skin to heal if it needs to. I hope rads go smoothly for you and you have a wonderful vacation.

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2007 08:11PM - edited Sep 9, 2007 08:12PM by maxgirl  My eyelashes and eyebrows got very sparse during Taxol, but even before they fell out, I stopped wearing mascara and started wearing eyeliner, which I don't usually do.  Sort of like getting your hair cut before it starts to fall out.  My wig has bangs so they covered some of the naked look along my eyebrows.  I used a brush coloring for the eyebrow line.  I'm almost 3 months out from my last chemo and my eyelashes and eyebrows are growing back in.  Tweezers won't work -- I need to use a lawnmower on my left eyebrow. All gray, too.
